questions.question_text: Connie is a tax preparer with a new client named Akeem. During their initial tax appointment, Connie reviews Akeem’s prior year return and discovers a serious error involving overstatement of charitable deductions. Akeem prepared the return himself and did not understand how to calculate his charitable deductions properly. At this point, what is Connie required to do?

options.A: She is not required to notify Akeem of the error on his prior year tax return, as long as she did not prepare the return in question.
options.B: She is required to notify Akeem of the error on his prior year tax return. She is not required to correct the error.
options.C: She is required to notify Akeem of the error on his prior year tax return. She is also required to correct the error, or she must disengage from the client.
options.D: She is required to notify Akeem of the error on his prior year tax return and the consequences of not correcting the error. She is not required to correct the error.

questions.question_text: Francine is an enrolled agent. She has a new client named Alexander. Alexander does not wish to efile his tax return, because he does not trust the Internet. Instead, he wishes to file on paper. However, Francine files more than 11 tax returns per year, and she is subject to the IRS preparer e-file mandate. What should Francine do in this case?

options.A: Francine must fire the client.
options.B: She is required to efile unless Alexander has a qualifying religious exception.
options.C: Francine may prepare a paper return and attach Form 8948, Preparer Explanation for Not Filing Electronically. The taxpayer must manually sign and mail the return.
options.D: None of the above.

options.B: The refund will be released if she files a hardship petition.
options.C: The refund will be allocated to a future tax debt.
options.D: The refund will be allocated ratably over the life of her installment agreement.

questions.topic: How Returns are Selected for Examination
questions.question_text: John is a self-employed, freelance graphic designer. During the year, he worked for several clients and received multiple Forms 1099-NEC (Nonemployee Compensation) from them, reporting his income. On his tax return, John reports gross income of $50,000 from his freelance work on Schedule C. The IRS also receives copies of the Forms 1099-NEC from John's clients. These forms show the following amounts: Client A: $20,000 Client B: $15,000 Client C: $25,000 The total income reported by the clients on the Forms 1099-NEC is $60,000. What is the likely outcome from this discrepancy?

options.A: The IRS will contact John to inform him of the discrepancy and will immediately assess additional tax.
options.B: The IRS will contact John to inform him of the discrepancy and will levy his bank account.
options.C: The IRS will contact the police to report tax evasion.
options.D: Due to this mismatch of third-party documentation, John's tax return will likely be flagged for examination.

Nasir has tried to recreate his records using reasonable estimates, but he has no receipts or other substantiation for any of the expenses. He does have proof of the destruction of his home in the form of photographs and insurance documents. What should Christina do in this case?

options.A: Christina can prepare the return using estimates only under the supervision of a licensed attorney.
options.B: Christina may prepare the return using estimates. She should disclose the use of estimates to the IRS.
options.C: Christina should refer Nasir to an attorney.
options.D: She cannot prepare a return using only estimates.

Malia has an ITIN, but she does not want to file jointly with Jacob. She does not have any U.S.-source income, and she does not want to be taxed on the income she earns in France. Based on this information, which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Jacob can use the married filing separately filing status.
options.B: Jacob is required to file jointly with his wife because she is automatically treated as a resident for tax purposes.
options.C: Jacob can file as head of household using his wife, Malia as his qualifying person for HOH.
options.D: Jacob must file jointly with his wife because she is a nonresident alien.

He earns too much to contribute to a Roth IRA or make a deductible contribution to a traditional IRA, and he has maxed out his contributions to his 401(k) plan at work. He has decided to make a contribution to his traditional IRA before the end of the year. Which of the following is true about his contribution?

options.A: He can make a nondeductible IRA contribution. His contribution will grow on a tax-deferred basis, despite the fact that it is nondeductible.
options.B: His distributions will not be taxed when he reaches retirement age, because he did not deduct the contribution when made.
options.C: He can contribute whatever amount he wishes, with no limits, because there are no tax benefits to his contribution.
options.D: He is not allowed to make a non-deductible contribution to a traditional IRA, because he is covered by a 401(k) plan at work.

options.A: The Schedule K-1 is informational only, Cecil will not owe any tax since any income earned by the estate will be tax-free to the beneficiaries.
options.B: Cecil should use the information on the Schedule K-1 and report the income on Schedule E of his Form 1040.
options.C: Cecil should use the information on the Schedule K-1 and report the income on Schedule C of his Form 1040.
options.D: Cecil should use the information on the Schedule K-1 and report the income on Schedule D of his Form 1040.

questions.question_text: Nash withdrew $10,000 from a one-year, deferred interest certificate of deposit. He had to pay an early withdrawal penalty of two months' interest, which totaled $112. Nash also earned $19 of interest from his other savings account during the year. What is the correct treatment of these transactions?

options.A: He must report the $19 as interest income. The early withdrawal penalty is not deductible.
options.B: He must report the $19 as interest income and he can claim the $112 penalty amount as an adjustment to income.
options.C: He must report the $19 as interest income. He can claim the $112 penalty amount if he itemizes deductions on Schedule A.
options.D: He is allowed to subtract the penalty from the interest he earned during the year. Therefore, he is not required to report the interest.

questions.question_text: The Umber Partnership is a cash-basis, calendar-year partnership. Umber Partnership has four equal partners: Harry, Susan, Karen, and Larry. On September 1st, Larry dies. Larry's eldest son, Perry, was designated as his successor in interest by the legal terms of his partnership agreement. The distributive share of partnership income allocable to Larry through the date of death was $8,000; for the entire year, it was $12,000. How should this income be reported by the Umber Partnership? (Choose the best answer)

options.A: Larry's final Schedule K-1 would report $8,000  in partnership income for the year. The remaining $4,000 would be reported to Perry, his successor.
options.B: Larry's final Schedule K-1 would report $8,000  in partnership income for the year. The remaining $4,000 would be reported to Larry's estate on Form 1041.
options.C: The full $12,000 should be reported to Perry on a Schedule K-1, because Larry cannot earn partnership income in the year of death.
options.D: The full $12,000 should be reported on Larry's final Schedule K-1 and reported on his Form 1040.

questions.question_text: Andrew is a financial planner who owns his own business. He invites his best client, Thomas, to a baseball game. While at the game, Andrew buys hot dogs and drinks for himself and his client for $40. While at the game, they discuss business and Thomas signs a contract for financial services. The baseball tickets cost $150 each. Andrew has a receipt for the baseball tickets. After the game, they go to a restaurant to discuss business. The cost of the restaurant meal is $52, plus a $8 tip, totals $60. Based on this information, what would Andrew's allowable deduction be for these expenses on his Schedule C?

options.A: Andrew can deduct $30, which is 50% of the restaurant meal, but the food purchased at the baseball game is included in the "entertainment" and therefore, nondeductible.
options.B: Andrew may take a deduction for 80% of the meal, hot dogs and drinks only ($80).
options.C: Andrew may take a deduction for 50% of the meal, hot dogs and drinks ($50), but not the cost of the baseball tickets.
options.D: Andrew may take a deduction for 100% of the meal as well as the cost of the baseball tickets.

What can she do, in order to pay her taxes as late as possible, (but not incur a penalty).

options.A: Francine can file her return early, and then pay her amount due as late as October 15, as long as she files a valid extension.
options.B: Francine can file her return early, and then pay her amount due as late as April 15,2025, and she will not owe a penalty.
options.C: Francine cannot file her return early, and then pay her amount due at a later date.
options.D: Francine can file her return early, and then pay her amount anytime before the end of the year, and she will not owe a penalty.

questions.topic: Business Income and Types of Income
questions.question_text: Janice is the sole proprietor of a nail salon that had a net profit of $25,000 for the year. Her husband, Marty, is also self-employed. Marty runs a carpentry business that had a net loss of ($1,500) for the year. Janice and Marty file jointly. How should their income and loss be reported?

options.A: Janice must file a Schedule C for the nail salon showing her net profit of $25,000, and Marty must file his own Schedule C for the carpentry business showing his net loss of $1,500. Janice’s Schedule SE will show total earnings subject to SE tax of $25,000.
options.B: Janice must file a Schedule C for the nail salon showing her net profit of $25,000, and Marty must file his own Schedule C for the carpentry business showing his net loss of $1,500. Janice’s Schedule SE will show total earnings subject to SE tax of $25,000. Marty’s Schedule SE will show a credit for $1,500 (the amount of his loss).
options.C: Janice and Marty can file a single Schedule C netting the income and loss from both businesses. Their Schedule SE will show total earnings subject to SE tax of $23,500.
options.D: Janice must file a Schedule C for the nail salon showing her net profit of $25,000, and Marty must file his own Schedule C for the carpentry business showing his net loss of $1,500. Their combined Schedule SE will show total earnings subject to SE tax of $23,500.

questions.question_text: Lorenzo is an international student and a junior at San Diego State University. He is a citizen of Spain lawfully present in the U.S. in F-1 immigration status. When he came to the U.S. to study three years ago, his parents gave him $20,000 in cash for his living expenses. Lorenzo applied for a scholarship while he was attending the university, and received $4,000 in scholarship funds, which he used to help pay his tuition. Is this taxable income to Lorenzo, who is classified as a nonresident alien for tax purposes?

options.A: Yes, the scholarship is taxable and must be reported on Form 1040-NR.
options.B: The scholarship is taxable and must be reported on Form 1040, not form 1040-NR.
options.C: The scholarship is not taxable and does not have to be reported on Form 1040-NR.
options.D: The scholarship is taxable and has to be reported on Form 1040-NR. He may offset any income tax by claiming the American Opportunity Tax Credit.

options.B: Alimony and child support payments are always are included in the gross income of the payee and are deductible from the gross income of the payor.

questions.question_text: Ophelia bought her principal residence in California for $250,000 on January 3, 2024. She sold it on December 23, 2024, (less than 12 months later) for $276,000 because she wanted to move in with her boyfriend. She also paid $14,000 in mortgage interest during the year. What is the amount and character of her gain on the sale?

options.A: $0 gain or loss, she qualifies for the Section 121 exclusion.
options.B: Short-term ordinary gain of $25,000.
options.C: Long-term capital gain of $12,000.
options.D: Short-term capital gain of $26,000.

questions.question_text: Rhonda had to give up her main home to foreclosure. She has a Form 1099-C, which shows the cancellation of her mortgage loan. Despite facing financial difficulties, she did not declare bankruptcy. She is also not insolvent because she has a retirement plan at work, but she does not want to withdraw from her retirement account. Rhonda confirmed that the entirety of the mortgage loan was used to buy the house. According to her Form 1099-C, $60,000 worth of debt was forgiven. How should this cancelled debt be reported on Rhonda's tax return?

options.A: No income or loss to report.
options.B: The cancelled debt is not taxable. She must report the amount qualifying for exclusion on Form 982 and attach the form to her tax return.
options.C: The cancellation of debt is fully taxable and must be reported as "other income" because she is not insolvent or in bankruptcy.
options.D: The cancellation of debt may be taxable, but only if she is required to file a tax return.

Rubina has a small part-time job and also receives investment income from stocks that were given to her by her aunt and uncle. In 2024, she received the following income: Dividends: $1,200 W-2 Wages: $2,200 Taxable interest: $1,300 Tax-exempt interest: $200 Capital gains: $500 Capital losses: ($300) Is Rubina subject to the kiddie tax, and what is her unearned income for the year?

options.A: Yes, she is subject to the kiddie tax. Her unearned income totals $2,700.
options.B: Yes, she is subject to the kiddie tax. Her unearned income totals $3,000.
options.C: No, she is not subject to the kiddie tax. Her unearned income totals $1,100.
options.D: Yes, she is subject to the kiddie tax. Her unearned income totals $2,900.

questions.question_text: An IRS revenue agent submits a lawful records request to Sylvia, an enrolled agent, for records relating to a former client, Hikaru, who is under IRS investigation. However, Sylvia had terminated their engagement when Hikaru failed to pay her for preparing his return. She returned his original records and did not keep the tax return she had prepared for him. Under Circular 230 §10.20, what is Sylvia obligated to do regarding this IRS records request?

options.A: She must promptly notify the IRS that she no longer has the records.
options.B: She does not need to respond to the request because he is no longer her client.
options.C: She must promptly notify the IRS that she no longer has the records and also attempt to contact her former client.
options.D: She must promptly notify the IRS that she no longer has the records; attempt to contact her former client; and contact third parties to try to locate the records.

questions.question_text: What is a "dual status" alien?

options.A: A dual-status alien is an individual who is married to a U.S. Citizen.
options.B: A dual-status alien is an individual who is considered to have been both a resident and a nonresident  in the same tax year.

options.B: The distribution was subject a 3% mandatory excise tax, and this must be paid in order to avoid the additional 10% penalty.
options.C: Chow-Lin has no recourse and must pay taxes and a 10% penalty on the entire distribution.
options.D: Chow-Lin has 60 days to deposit an amount equal to the gross distribution into an IRA if he wants to avoid taxes and penalties.

options.A: Griselda must return all of Bruno's records. She cannot bill him for her time.
options.B: Upon demand, Griselda must return all documents necessary for her client to fulfill his tax obligations. She is also required to give him a copy of the tax return she prepared, regardless of a fee dispute.
options.C: Griselda may retain all the records until the fee is paid. However, Bruno may sue Griselda for the return of the records.
options.D: Upon demand, Griselda must return all documents necessary for her client to fulfill his tax obligations. She is not required to give him a copy of the tax return she prepared, or any other work that the client has not paid for.

options.A: Her tax return should include the cancelled debt on Schedule D. All the cancelled debt is taxable.

options.A: It is taxable to Iwan and must be included in his gross income on Form 1040. The executor fees are "other income" and not subject to self-employment tax.
options.B: It must be reported on his tax return but it is excluded from income.
options.C: It is not taxable and not reportable, because the executor fees are treated as an inheritance.
options.D: It must be included in gross income, and Iwan will be required to pay self-employment tax on the amount received.

questions.question_text: Kendra bought a new car for $30,000. She made a $5,000 down payment and borrowed the remaining $25,000 from her bank via a recourse loan. After she stopped making payments, the bank repossessed the car. The balance due on the loan at the time of the repossession was $15,000. The FMV of the car when repossessed was $12,000. She later receives a 1099-C for the canceled debt. She was not insolvent when the debt was canceled, because she has $40,000 in a traditional IRA account. What amount is Kendra’s loss and what amount must she report as cancellation of debt income?

options.A: $13,000 deductible loss; $0 COD.
options.B: $18,000 nondeductible loss; $3,000 COD.
options.C: $13,000 nondeductible loss; $3,000 COD.
options.D: $15,000 nondeductible loss; $12,000 COD.

questions.question_text: Alexis is 56 and wants to claim her son, Theodore, for EITC. Theodore is 29 years old, unmarried, and is permanently disabled from a serious car accident that he sustained on March 1, 2024. Before March, he was not disabled, but his doctor said that Theodore is permanently disabled now due to the accident. Theodore lived with his mother, Alexis, in the U.S. for over 6 months in the last part of the year, and Alexis provided more than half of her son's support, as well as paying the majority of his medical bills. No one else lived in the home. Both have valid Social Security numbers. Theodore worked at the beginning of the year, and earned $14,800 in wages before he sustained his accident on March 1. Does Alexis qualify to claim her son Theodore as a qualifying child, and why or why not?

options.A: No, Alexis cannot claim Theodore as her qualifying child because his income is over the exemption amount for the year. However, she can claim her son as a qualifying relative the following year if he has zero income.
options.B: No, Alexis cannot claim Theodore as her qualifying child because his income is over the gross income limit for qualifying relatives.
options.C: No, Alexis cannot claim Theodore as her qualifying child because he is over 24 years of age and not a full-time student.
options.D: Yes, Alexis can claim Theodore as her qualifying child because his doctor determined he cannot work because of his disability, and his disability is permanent.

questions.question_text: Antrim and Deborah are in the process of adopting a little girl from the U.S. foster care system. options.A: A taxpayer can claim medical expenses only for a biological child or a stepchild.

questions.question_text: Arturo is a 10% shareholder of a family-owned C corporation that sells appliances. He is also an employee of the company and works as a full-time appliance salesman. The company pays Arturo the following: Mortgage and property taxes for his personal home: $48,000 Company car to make sales calls: $12,000 Medical and dental benefits: $18,000 W-2 Wages: $50,000 During the year, the corporation goes under IRS audit, and several of the payments are disallowed by the auditor. How could this affect Arturo's personal tax return?

options.A: It would not affect Arturo's personal income tax return, because a C corporation is not a pass-through entity.
options.B: The IRS may reclassify the mortgage and property taxes, medical and dental benefits, and the wages as a constructive distribution.
options.C: The IRS would likely reclassify the mortgage and property taxes as a constructive distribution. The reclassified distributions would be taxable to Arturo as a dividend, and not deductible by the C corporation.
options.D: All the payments would be treated as taxable distributions to Arturo, but still fully deductible by the corporation.

options.D: No, Gregory can charge a fee for offering direct deposit.

questions.question_text: Angela is a tax preparer. She has three clients who all share the same bank account (two elderly parents and an adult son, who has check-signing authority over all his parents' accounts). These three taxpayers would all like to direct deposit their tax refunds into this single bank account, but all of them will file separate returns. Is this permitted?

options.A: Each taxpayer must have their own separate bank account in order to deposit their refunds. But they can request a paper check from the IRS instead.
options.B: The parents would be able to deposit their refunds into a single account, but the son would have to have a separate bank account for his refund.
options.C: Yes, because a single financial account is limited to 3 electronically-deposited tax refunds per tax year. So even if all the taxpayers file a separate return, they can use the same bank account to deposit their refunds.
options.D: No, the taxpayers cannot deposit more than one tax refund per bank account.

options.B: The Schedule M-1 must be prepared by corporations with gross receipts or total assets of $500,000 or more. The Schedule M-3 must be prepared by corporations reporting gross assets of $50 million or more in assets.
options.C: The Schedule M-1 must be prepared by corporations with gross receipts or total assets of $50,000 or more. The Schedule M-3 must be prepared by corporations reporting gross assets of $5 million or more in assets.
options.D: The Schedule M-1 must be prepared by corporations with gross receipts or total assets of $250,000 or more. The Schedule M-3 must be prepared by corporations reporting gross assets of $10 million or more in assets.

questions.topic: Farming Businesses - Postponing Gains and Government Payments
questions.question_text: Hashir is a qualified farmer who raises large turkeys for resale. During the year, his property is affected by a flood, and he is forced to sell all his turkeys in a big hurry. The flooded area is later designated for federal disaster assistance. Hashir would not normally sell all his livestock in a single year, and he would like to postpone some of the gain. What must a Hashir demonstrate to qualify for postponing gain due to weather conditions?

options.A: He must prove that the livestock was sold prematurely.
options.B: He must show that the livestock was sold due to a weather-related condition.

questions.question_text: Helene’s father died on October 9, 2024. He left his entire estate, which consisted primarily of stock and vacant land, to Helene, his daughter. Her father’s basis in all the assets was $1.5 million. On the date of his death, the estate’s fair market value was $7 million ($2 million for the stock and $5 million for the land). Six months after his death (the alternate valuation date) the assets were valued at $6.9 million, because the value of her late father's stock had gone down. No estate tax return was filed (Form 706), because the estate's value was under the exemption threshold. What is Helene’s basis in the estate property?

options.A: $6.9 million
options.B: $7 million
options.C: $1.5 million
options.D: $5.5 million

questions.question_text: Paul is a full-time employee of Carpet Warehouse. Paul frequently travels to meet with customers. Paul's employer gives him $500 a month ($6,000 for the year) for his business expenses. Paul does not have to provide any proof of his expenses to his employer and he can keep any funds that he does not spend. His actual expenses for the year were $1,000 for lodging, $600 for meals while away from home, and $2,000 for entertainment, when he took 5 of his best vendors out to a baseball game. What reporting is required of Paul's employer and what reporting is required of Paul?

options.A: Employer adds $6,000 to wages reported on Paul's Form W-2; Paul cannot deduct the expenses on his tax return.
options.B: Employer adds $6,000 to wages reported on Paul's Form W-2; Paul can report $1,600 as a miscellaneous itemized deduction on Schedule A
options.C: Employer adds $6,000 to wages reported on Paul's Form W-2; Paul can report $1,600 as an adjustment to income.
options.D: Employer adds $6,000 to wages reported on Paul's Form W-2; Paul can report $3,600 as a miscellaneous itemized deduction on Schedule A

questions.question_text: Prisha works full-time as a cashier, but she also has a hobby as a landscape artist. She sells her paintings mostly at county fairs. Sometimes she gives them to friends and family, but she mostly paints for pleasure and would continue painting, even if she did not make any money selling her paintings. She had various expenses related to her hobby, such as travel and meals to the county fairs where she would display her artwork for sale. Prisha’s hobby generates some income, but her expenses exceed her income this year. What can Prisha do with her hobby losses?

options.A: She can deduct the hobby loss from other income, but only if the income is from passive sources.
options.B: Her hobby loss cannot be deducted.
options.C: She can deduct the hobby loss against capital gains income.
options.D: She can carry the hobby loss forward to future years, for when her hobby earns more revenue.

questions.question_text: Consuela has cerebral palsy. She cannot climb stairs or bathe herself. On her doctor's advice and with her landlord's permission, she pays a building contractor to install a bathroom with modifications on the first floor of the two-story house that she rents. Although the landlord allowed the improvements, he did not pay any of the cost of buying and installing the special accommodations. Consuela does not own the home. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Consuela cannot deduct any of the expenses because none were for the actual treatment of her medical condition.
options.B: Consuela can deduct a portion of the expenses as an adjustment to income on Form 1040.
options.C: Consuela cannot deduct any of the expenses as a medical expense because she does not legally own the home.
options.D: Consuela can deduct the entire amount she paid for the upgrades as a medical expense on Schedule A.

options.B: Yes. Although Mariposa is allowed to advertise on television, she is not allowed to imply she can receive special treatment from any IRS employee.

The owner instructs Lottie to delay depositing employment taxes until the company is on sounder financial footing. Lottie agrees to do so. What are the potential consequences of this action?

options.A: Both the owner and Lottie could be personally liable for a penalty equal to the full amount of the unpaid trust fund tax, plus interest.
options.B: Lottie could be personally liable for a penalty equal to the full amount of the unpaid trust fund tax.
options.C: Both the owner and Lottie could be personally liable for a penalty equal to the full amount of the unpaid trust fund tax, but only the owner of the business would be responsible for paying any interest on the amount due.
options.D: The owner could be personally liable for a penalty equal to the full amount of the unpaid trust fund tax.

questions.question_text: Aberdare Realty, Inc. is a C Corporation that owns a hotel that it rents out to business guests. During the year, the hotel is flooded, and the property incurs $45,000 of flood damage. Aberdare Realty, Inc. believes that its property insurance will cover the loss, and the company immediately files a claim. Aberdare Realty, Inc. files its 2024 corporate tax return on February 15, 2025. The business does not report the casualty loss on its tax return because Aberdare Realty expects to get fully reimbursed by the insurance company. The insurance company later denies the claim because the policy did not cover flood damage. What should Aberdare Realty do?

options.A: Aberdare Realty may carry the loss back 5 years, since it is a corporate capital loss
options.B: Aberdare Realty's only legal remedy is to sue the insurance company.
options.C: Aberdare Realty may amend its corporate tax return to claim the casualty loss.
options.D: Aberdare Realty can only carry the loss forward to a future tax year.

options.A: Jose can amend Greer's return to a joint return without her consent, because they are married.
options.B: Both are required to file tax returns.

questions.topic: Medical, Dental, Vision, and Long-Term Care Expenses
questions.question_text: Omar properly filed his 2024 income tax return. Omar becomes ill shortly thereafter. He died on May 1, 2025, with unpaid medical expenses of $5,500 from 2024 and $5,800 in 2025. Omar's executor is his sister, Mary. She pays all of the outstanding medical bills on December 31, 2025, out of the estate's funds. As Omar's executor, she would like to deduct as many medical expenses for Omar as possible. How should the medical expenses be deducted?

options.A: Omar's executor can file an amended return for 2024 claiming a deduction based on the $5,500 medical expenses. The $5,800 of medical expenses from 2025 can be included on Omar's final return for 2025.
options.B: The executor cannot claim any medical expenses for Omar, because the amounts were paid after his death.
options.C: Omar's executor should file an amended return for 2024 claiming a deduction for all the medical expenses.
options.D: Omar's sister can claim a deduction for all her brother's medical expenses on her own tax return, since she is the one who paid them.

questions.question_text: Jenny is a 1% partner in Balton Partnership, which is a limited liability company and a manufacturing business. Jenny is a limited partner and has no day-to-day involvement in the business. The Balton Partnership has $100,000 in losses for the year, $5,000 of which are allocated to Jenny on her Schedule K-1. As a limited partner, is Jenny allowed to deduct her partnership losses?

options.A: Yes, her losses are fully deductible against any other type of income.
options.B: Yes, but her losses can only offset other income from passive activities.
options.C: Yes, but her deductible losses are limited to $3,000. Any remaining losses must be carried forward.
options.D: No, she cannot deduct her partnership losses. She must carry the losses forward until the partnership is profitable or until she disposes of her partnership interest.

What are the taxable repercussions of this event? Does she need to pay taxes on the additional stock that she received as the result of a stock split?

options.A: This is a taxable event, and Jennifer must pay tax on the value of the additional shares.
options.B: This is not a taxable event, but Jennifer must report the stock split on Schedule D.
options.C: This is a taxable event, and Jennifer must pay estimated taxes on the newly acquired shares.
options.D: This is not a taxable event, but Jennifer must reallocate her basis between the original shares and the shares newly acquired in the stock split.

questions.question_text: Kaitlin owns a residential rental property. The sewage and water bill is in Kaitlin's name because she is the owner of the property. Her tenant pays the sewage bill for her rental property and deducts the amount from the normal rent payment. Under the terms of the lease, her tenant doesn’t have to pay this bill. How should Kaitlin treat this transaction on her Schedule E?

options.A: She must include the utility bill paid by the tenant as a rental payment in her rental income. She can deduct the utility payment made by the tenant as a rental expense.
options.B: The property owner can deduct the utility payment made by the tenant as a rental expense on Schedule E.
options.C: The property owner must report the utility payment made by the tenant as rental income on Schedule E. No amounts are deductible in this scenario.
options.D: No reporting is required, since the amounts paid by the tenant are a "wash".

options.C: If capital is not a material income-producing factor, family members must have agreed that contributions of each entitles them to a share in the profits and that some capital or service is provided by each member.
options.D: If capital is not a material income-producing factor; the family members must have joined together in good faith to conduct a business.

questions.topic: Farming Businesses - Income Averaging and Other Tax Rules
questions.question_text: Many years ago, Bonfield Farms, LLC constructed a barn to store farm equipment at a cost of $50,000. In May of this year, the barn had a fair market value of $70,000. In June, the barn was completely destroyed by a tornado. At the time of the tornado, Bonfield Farms had an adjusted basis of $0 in the property (it was fully depreciated). Bonfield Farms received $70,000 from their casualty insurance company. Bonfield Farms spent $66,000 to rebuild the barn. What is the tax consequence of this event?

options.A: Bonfield Farms must include $4,000 ($70,000 – $66,000) in taxable income. The company can choose to postpone the remaining $66,000 gain.
options.B: Bonfield Farms must include $70,000 as a capital gain from an involuntary conversion, but the $66,000 that was spent to rebuild the barn may be deducted using Section 179.
options.C: It is a nontaxable event.
options.D: Bonfield Farms must include $70,000 in taxable income, but the $66,000 that was spent to rebuild the barn may be deducted as a business expense.

Does Gwendolyn still pass the residency test, and can her mother Rhiannon still claim Gwendolyn as a qualifying child on her tax return?

options.A: Gwendolyn passes the residency test, but her mother cannot claim her as a qualifying child because Gwendolyn is more than 19 years old.

options.C: No, Gwendolyn does not pass the residency test for a qualifying child because she did not live with her mother for at least six months of the year.

questions.question_text: Janet is unmarried and files single. This year, Janet earned $99,800 in income from various income sources. The total tax liability shown on Janet’s prior-year return was $10,900. After estimating her allowable deductions and credits, her expected tax liability for 2024 is $14,000. The tax expected to be withheld in 2024 from her wages is $11,100. She plans to file right on April 15, 2025 the filing deadline, and pay any tax owed at the same time. Will Janet be subject to an estimated tax penalty when she files her return?

options.A: Janet will not be subject to the estimated tax penalty because she owes less than the deemed personal exemption amount when she files her return.
options.B: Janet will not be subject to the estimated tax penalty because she paid at least 100% of the tax shown on her return for the prior year.
options.C: Yes, Janet will be subject to the estimated tax penalty if she does not adjust her withholding or make estimated tax payments, because she will owe more than $1,000 when she files her return.
options.D: As long as Janet files her return and pays by March 1, she will not owe an estimated tax penalty.

While she was away visiting friends, she rented her condo for 13 days, charging $100 per day for a total of $1,300. She also had $320 of expenses during that time. How should this rental income be reported?

options.A: She should report the income as ordinary income on Form 1040. The expenses are deductible as a miscellaneous itemized deduction on Schedule A, if she itemizes deductions.
options.B: The income is not taxable and does not need to be reported. The expenses are not deductible.
options.C: She should report all the rental income. She can deduct $320 of expenses on Schedule E.
options.D: She can deduct the expenses. The rental income is not taxable.

questions.question_text: Fatima has a full-time job, and she is also self-employed as a part time Uber driver, which she does on weekends. She doesn't want to pay estimated payments, so she increases her withholding at her regular job. She always files her return on time. How much tax must she pay, in order to avoid an estimated tax penalty when she files her return?

options.A: She will avoid the estimated tax penalty if she owes less than $500 in tax after subtracting her withholding and credits, or if she paid at least 90% of the tax for the current year, or 100% of the tax shown on the return for the prior year, (whichever is smaller).
options.B: She will avoid the estimated tax penalty if she owes less than $1,000 in tax after subtracting her withholding and credits, or if she paid at least 90% of the tax for the current year, or 100% of the tax shown on the return for the prior year, (whichever is smaller).
options.C: She will avoid the estimated tax penalty if she owes less than $5,000 in tax after subtracting her withholding and credits, or if she paid at least 90% of the tax for the current year, or 100% of the tax shown on the return for the prior year, (whichever is smaller).
options.D: She will avoid the estimated tax penalty if she owes less than $2,500 in tax after subtracting her withholding and credits, or if she paid at least 90% of the tax for the current year, or 100% of the tax shown on the return for the prior year, (whichever is smaller).

questions.question_text: Angelo, an unmarried taxpayer, owns a rental property that he actively manages himself. He collects the rents and chooses the tenants. He also works full-time as a math tutor. Angelo had the following income and loss during the tax year. Salary from his tutoring job $42,300 Dividends 300 Interest from a CD 1,400 Rental loss (5,000) The rental loss came from the house, which he owns. Although he actively participated in the rental activity, he is not a real estate professional. Based on this information, how much of the rental loss is Angelo permitted to deduct against his other taxable income in the current year?

options.A: He may not deduct any of the losses in the current year, because he has no passive activity income to offset. The full amount must be carried over to future years.
options.B: He may deduct the full amount of his losses ($5,000) against his wages.
options.C: Up to $1,700 in losses, to offset the amount of his dividends and interest ($300 + $1,400)
options.D: Up to $3,000 in losses, the maximum capital loss limit for an individual taxpayer.

questions.question_text: Perry is an ordained minister of the Holy Revival Church in Florida. In the current year, he receives the following: W-2 salary from the church: $50,000 Housing allowance for rent and utilities: $20,000 Fees for performing weddings and funerals: $5,000 How are these amounts taxed under the special rules for members of the clergy?

options.A: Perry has to pay both income tax and self-employment tax on his salary and the fees for performing weddings and funerals. He has to pay self-employment tax for the housing allowance, but it is not subject to income tax.
options.B: Perry must claim the salary, housing allowance, and fees as income on his tax return. The salary and fees are subject to income tax and self-employment tax. However, the housing allowance is subject to income tax only.
options.C: Because his church is tax-exempt, Perry does not have to report any wages received from the church. However, the fees for performing weddings and funerals are taxable income.
options.D: Because he is an ordained minister, Perry's salary and housing allowance are not subject to income tax. However, he must pay self-employment tax on both his salary and the housing allowance.

Barney also paid $5,000 in foreign property taxes on a second residence that he owns in Greece, and $400 in foreign sales taxes when he purchased a vehicle for use when he travels overseas. How much of these amounts would be a qualified foreign tax, eligible for a credit or deduction on Barney's individual tax return?

She does not receive any cash, because Solar Brokers does not have any readily available cash to distribute. The plot of land has an adjusted basis to the partnership of $5,000 and a fair market value of $40,000 (it has increased in value over the years that the partnership has owned it). options.A: Community property laws state that each spouse is entitled to 50% of total community income and expenses, so they must divide their income equally on their separate returns.
options.B: Community property laws state that each spouse is entitled to 100% of total community income and expenses, so they must report 100% of each spouse's income on each separate return.

questions.question_text: Garland has a partial interest in several partnerships. He is merely a passive investor and does not materially participate in any of the businesses. The income is reported to Garland on (multiple) Schedules K-1. During the year, Garland had the following results from these passive activities: French-style Cafe: $56,000 loss. Ice cream store: $32,000 loss. Nutrition supplement store: $18,000 loss. Doughnut shop: $90,000 income. What is the tax treatment of Garland's ownership of these businesses, and how would the amounts be reported on his Form 1040?

options.A: No taxable income; carryover of passive activity losses of $16,000 to the following year. The amounts would be reported on Schedule E.
options.B: Deductible capital loss of $16,000 in the tax year. The amounts would be reported on Schedule D.
options.C: Taxable income of $90,000; carryover of passive activity losses of $106,000 to the following year. The amounts would be reported on Schedule E.
options.D: Taxable income of $90,000 and deductible losses of $106,000. The amounts would be reported on Schedule C.

questions.question_text: Deena's tax return was selected for IRS audit. She had claimed three children as her dependents on the return, and received the Earned Income Tax Credit. During the audit, the IRS discovers that the children are not Deena's children, and she had used stolen Social Security numbers and made false statements on the return. Because of this fraud, the IRS auditor disallows her EITC refund claim. How many years can the IRS ban Deena from claiming the EITC?

options.A: Two-year ban for fraud.
options.B: The IRS cannot ban a taxpayer from claiming refundable credits if the taxpayer is legally entitled to them in subsequent years.
options.C: Permanent ban for fraud.
options.D: Ten-year ban for fraud.

questions.question_text: Hasan owes $7,500 to the IRS, which he could not pay immediately, so he applied for an installment agreement. He was paying his monthly payments on time, but six months later, he was a victim of ID theft and his bank account was frozen and he could not withdraw any funds or pay his bills. In the meantime, Hasan received notification that his installment agreement had been rescinded because he missed his payment. Hasan wants to appeal the cancellation of his installment agreement by filing a CAP Appeal in order to get his installment agreement reinstated. What should Hasan do to request a CAP appeal?

options.A: To appeal an installment agreement that has been terminated, Hasan should complete Form 9423, Collection Appeal Request.
options.B: To appeal an installment agreement that has been terminated, Hasan should complete Form 2848, Power of Attorney.
options.C: To appeal an installment agreement that has been terminated, Hasan should complete Form 656-L, Offer in Compromise (Doubt as to Liability).
options.D: To appeal an installment agreement that has been terminated, Hasan should complete Form 2848, Power of Attorney.

questions.topic: S Corps - Income and Expenses and Distributions
questions.question_text: Greer is a 10% shareholder in Lewisville Design, Inc. an S corporation that offers interior design services. Lewisville Design has a net operating loss (NOL) in 2024, and Greer's distributive share of ordinary losses are ($32,000) on her Schedule K-1. Greer's stock basis is $30,000 before consideration of the losses. How should these losses be treated on Greer's individual tax return?

options.A: She can claim up to $30,000 of the losses. The $2,000 in excess losses are lost forever and cannot be carried over.
options.B: She can claim up to $30,000 of the losses. The $2,000 in excess losses are not allowable in the current year and are suspended and carried over to the subsequent year.
options.C: She can claim $32,000 of the losses. Her stock basis would then be zero.
options.D: She cannot claim any of the losses, because it would reduce her shareholder basis to zero.

How would this sale be reported by Moses on his individual tax return?

options.A: Moses will recognize a capital loss of $4,000 on the sale. He should report the loss on Forms 8949 and Schedules D.
options.B: Moses will recognize an ordinary loss of $4,000 on the sale. He should report the loss on Schedule E.
options.C: Moses will recognize a capital gain of $4,000 on the sale. He should report the gain on Forms 8949 and Schedules D.

questions.question_text: The IRS sends an audit letter to Polly's old address. The letter is then forwarded to her new address. In response to the letter, Polly notifies the IRS of the new address and requests a transfer of the audit to an office closer to the new address. The manager approves the transfer request, but the manager falls ill with food poisoning that very day and forgets to submit the necessary paperwork for nearly three months. In the meantime, interest and penalties have been accruing on Polly's tax account. Can Polly request an abatement of interest in this case?

options.A: No, Polly cannot request an abatement of interest due to unreasonable error or delay, because she did not follow proper IRS procedures and file a formal change of address with the IRS.
options.B: Polly cannot request an abatement of interest, but she may be able to request an abatement of her additional penalties.
options.C: Yes, Polly can request an abatement of interest due to unreasonable error or delay in performing a ministerial or managerial act.
options.D: Polly can only request an abatement of interest due to unreasonable error or delay if she files a petition with the U.S. Tax Court.

The four sisters paid the following amounts toward their mother's total support of $50,000: Karlita: $12,500 Melissa: $12,500 Gina: $20,000 Megan: $5,000 Who among the four sisters could claim their mother as a dependent under a written multiple support agreement?

options.A: Only Gina
options.B: Any of the four sisters could potentially claim the dependency exemption, if they are in agreement
options.C: Either Gina, Karlita, or Melissa
options.D: None of the sisters can claim their mother

questions.question_text: Wally received a qualified disaster distribution from his traditional IRA in the amount of $90,000 in 2023. Wally elected to have the full income from the distribution recognized in 2023, and it was properly reported on his return. In 2024, he changes his mind and decides to repay the distribution. He makes a repayment of $45,000 on December 1, 2024. How should this repayment be reported?

options.A: The entire $45,000 repayment must be carried forward to 2025.
options.B: The entire $45,000 repayment must be carried back to 2023, the year the distribution was made. The repayment will be treated as a rollover.
options.C: The entire repayment of $45,000 will offset income in 2024.
options.D: The repayment of $45,000 will not be reported, it is treated as a nondeductible contribution in 2024.

options.C: The full amount of the standard deduction is allowed on the taxpayer's final Form 1040, regardless of the fact that the taxpayer was only alive for one month of the taxable year.
options.D: A deceased taxpayer is forced to itemize deductions, since they were not alive for the entire year.

questions.question_text: Michael works for Sloppy Auto, Inc, and earns $150,000 in wages. His boss switches payroll providers in the middle of the year, and as a result, Michael's Social Security taxes were over-withheld. Michael tells his boss about the error, but his employer refuses to fix the W-2 or the withholding. Michael has only worked for Sloppy Auto during the year and does not have any other job. Does Michael have any recourse in this case?

options.A: Michael can request a refund of excess withholding directly from the Social Security office.
options.B: Michael can simply take a credit on his return, no additional forms are necessary.
options.C: Michael can fill out IRS Form 843, Claim for Refund and Request for Abatement to request a refund of excess withholding.
options.D: Michael cannot request a refund of the excess withholding. The employer must correct it.

questions.question_text: Katrina 60, and Bradley, 61, are married and file jointly. Neither are real estate professionals, but they own a rental property that they actively manage themselves. questions.topic: Penalties for Failure to Exercise Due Diligence
questions.question_text: Siobhan hires Emerson, to prepare her income tax returns. Emerson has prepared tax returns for several years but is not a CPA, an attorney, or an enrolled agent. Although he knows that Siobhan is single and childless, he prepares her tax return based on head of household filing status with two qualifying children so that Siobhan may qualify for the Earned Income Tax Credit, and thus a larger refund. Siobhan reviews a copy of the tax return and signs it. Emerson also signs the return and submits it to the IRS for processing. If the IRS detects the fraudulent credit, which of the two, if either, will face potential penalties?

options.A: Both Emerson and Siobhan will face penalties.
options.B: Only Siobhan, because she is legally responsible for the accuracy of her own return.
options.C: Neither should face any penalties because Emerson is not an enrolled preparer.
options.D: Emerson only.

questions.topic: Seeking Relief from Joint Liability (Including Innocent Spouse)
questions.question_text: Daren and Corrine are married and usually file jointly. Krista is their tax preparer. This year, Daren approaches Krista and tells her that he thinks his wife might have unreported income, because she is selling products online, but she doesn't want to report the income. He is afraid that they will get a 1099K for the amounts that his wife is earning online, and then they will both be responsible for a lot more tax. He doesn't want to be responsible for his wife's additional tax from the unreported income if the IRS audits them later. As Daren's tax preparer, what should Krista tell Daren?

options.A: Krista should fire both clients and never speak to them again.
options.B: Krista should encourage Daren to file as an "injured spouse".
options.C: Krista may need to discuss the concept of joint and several liability with Daren. Daren may want to consider filing a separate return from his wife.
options.D: Krista should prepare their return normally. Daren does not need to worry about his wife's unreported income.

questions.question_text: Gregory's tax return was selected for examination. The IRS determined that he claimed several children that were not his. The children were not related to him at all, and were actually the children of his neighbor, Tiffany. Gregory paid Tiffany $2,000 in order to "claim" her dependents. The IRS determined that Gregory fraudulently claimed the EITC and the Child Tax Credit on his return. In addition to any penalties and disallowance of the credits, the IRS may also prohibit Gregory from claiming these credits on future returns. How many years can the IRS ban Gregory from claiming future credits?

options.A: A permanent ban.
options.B: Five years.

questions.question_text: Bernice prepared her client's 2024 tax return on January 30, 2025. The client, Rudolf, had claimed three children as his dependents, claiming EITC for each child, and also claimed head of household status. Bernice didn't ask any questions about the children, or collect any documents. Rudolf's return was later audited by the IRS, and it was discovered that he had claimed his girlfriend's children, who were not related to him (Rudolf and his girlfriend are not married). All of the EITC credits for the three children, and the HOH status on Rudolf's return were disallowed. What kind of penalty can apply to Bernice, the preparer of the return in this case?

options.A: The IRS may assess a penalty of $1,000 per return against Bernice.
options.B: The IRS may assess a penalty of $635 per failure against Bernice.
options.C: No penalty. All the penalties will apply to Rudolf.
options.D: The IRS may assess a penalty of $55 per failure against Bernice.

options.C: Since they do not have a formal marriage license, they are each considered "single" for tax purposes.
options.D: They are considered to be partners in a civil union.

options.B: The LLC is converted from a disregarded entity to a partnership when Stephen contributes cash to the LLC. Nadine must recognize $10,000 of ordinary income from Stephen’s contribution to the business.

options.D: The LLC is converted from a sole proprietorship to a partnership when Stephen contributes cash to the LLC and receives his ownership stake. Neither partner recognizes gain or loss as a result of the conversion of the disregarded entity to a partnership.

options.A: The non-cash tip is taxable to her employer, but not to Frannie, since it is not made with cash.
options.B: The non-cash tip is taxable to Frannie, and must be reported to her employer and added to her Form W-2 as wages.
options.C: The non-cash tip is not taxable to Frannie, and does not need to be reported on her tax return.
options.D: The non-cash tip is taxable to Frannie, and must be reported on her tax return. She does not have to report the non-cash tip to her employer.

There is a legitimate dispute as to whether Brandy actually owes the tax, because the tax was assessed based on a lawsuit settlement that she never received. She believes the amounts have been miscalculated and the current amount owed is incorrect. If you were advising Brandy what to do, which type of Offer in Compromise would you recommend that she submit?

options.B: She should submit an OIC under "Effective tax administration".

options.D: She should submit an OIC under "Doubt as to collectability".

questions.question_text: Amelie and Danny are married and have always filed jointly. This year, they receive an audit notice that their prior year return is being examined by the IRS. Amelie hires Carole, an enrolled agent, to represent her in the examination of her joint return. Danny does not want to hire anybody and decides to ignore the audit notice and not respond to the IRS at all. Danny also refuses to speak to Carole. Is Carole still allowed to represent Amelie before the IRS, even though it is a joint return?

options.A: Carole cannot represent Amelie, because this is a clear conflict of interest.
options.B: Carole cannot represent Amelie by herself, and must obtain a signed power of attorney from Danny, as well, before she can represent the married couple.
options.C: Carole can represent Amelie by herself, as long as Amelie signs Form 8821 to designate Carole as her representative.
options.D: Yes, Carole can represent Amelie by herself, as long as Amelie signs Form 2848 to designate Carole as her representative.

questions.question_text: Tingey Construction is an LLC that made an S-election five years ago, and has been operating as an S corporation since then. On June 1, the corporation creates a second class of stock with different distribution and voting rights. What is the effect of this transaction on the corporation?

options.A: This transaction has no effect on the corporation.
options.B: Tingey Construction ceases to be an S corporation on June 1. The corporation will be taxed as a C corporation from that day forward.

questions.question_text: Mohammad runs his own farming business as a sole proprietor. In 2024 his business was affected by a FEMA disaster and incurs a net operating loss of ($45,000). Mohammad  does not have insurance to cover the loss, so Mohammad chooses to carryback his farming loss, and he wants to get a refund as quickly as possible. The farm had $59,000 in profits in the prior year, which was the first year of operations for the business. What is the easiest way for Mohammad to carryback his net operating losses?

options.A: By contacting the IRS disaster hotline directly, and requesting an expedited refund based on the FEMA disaster.
options.B: By filing another original return for the year in which the NOL arose.
options.C: By filing a complete, amended return before April 15, 2025.
options.D: By filing Form 1045 prior to December 31, 2025.

questions.question_text: Amos is a tax return preparer. His client, Jolene, told him that she had made several gifts during 2024 and asked if she should file a gift tax return, and if so, how much tax she would owe. Jolene has never given a taxable gift before. Jolene’s gift transactions were as follows: Paid her parents’ medical bills, $14,000 for her father and $18,000 for her mother Bought a sports car for her grandson, cost was $32,000 Gave $19,000 in cash to her church Prepared her last will leaving her vacation cabin, valued at $75,000, to her sister Sent a wedding gift of $11,000 to her niece What is Amos’ best answer to Jolene's questions?

options.A: No return is due because all the gifts are excluded.
options.B: Must file a gift tax return but no tax will be owed because of the standard deduction.
options.C: Must file a gift tax return and will owe gift tax on $32,000.
options.D: Must file a gift tax return but no tax will be owed because of the unified credit.

options.B: He is required to amend his prior year tax return to report the taxable refund.

questions.question_text: Roberto is a 40% partner in the Crestline Partnership, LLC, a company that sells medical supplies. Crestline Partnership dissolves during the year, and Roberto receives a proportionate liquidating distribution of $2,000 in cash and inventory (unsold electronics supplies) with a basis to the partnership of $7,000. Roberto's outside basis in the partnership is $10,000 on the date of the distribution. After this liquidating distribution, Crestline Partnership officially liquidates and the business closes its doors. How would this transaction be reported on Roberto's individual return?

options.A: Roberto recognizes a capital loss of $1,000. He should report the loss on Forms 8949 and Schedules D.
options.B: Roberto recognizes an ordinary loss of $1,000. He should report the loss on Schedule E.
options.C: Roberto recognizes a capital loss of $1,000, and an ordinary loss of $7,000. He should report the ordinary loss on Schedule E, and the capital loss on Schedule D.
options.D: Roberto recognizes a capital loss of $6,000. He should report the loss on Forms 8949 and Schedules D.

questions.question_text: Silver Gate Media, Inc. is an S corporation with four shareholders. The corporation has 20,000 shares outstanding. The shareholders have the following ownership: Debbie: 9,000 shares Soren: 4,000 shares Dino: 4,000 shares Jenna: 3,000 shares Total: 20,000 shares Jenna and Debbie wish to terminate the S election, in order to become a C corporation, but Soren and Dino do not wish to terminate the S election. Which statement is correct?

options.A: Debbie can elect to terminate the corporation’s S status on her own.
options.B: Jenna and Debbie have enough stock ownership to terminate the election without the consent of the remaining shareholders.
options.C: At least 75% of the shareholders with active ownership must agree to the termination.
options.D: All of the shareholders must agree to terminate the election.

questions.question_text: Angelica is an enrolled agent that employs 5 preparers at her tax preparation office. She discovers that one of her preparers, Darren, has been improperly inflating deductions on multiple client's returns. Angelica immediately fires Darren. Can Angelica be liable for Darren's misconduct?

options.A: Angelica will not be subject to a due diligence penalty for a return or claim prepared by her employee, but she can be subject to censure.
options.B: Yes, Angelica can be subject to a due diligence penalty for a return or claim prepared by her employee.
options.C: No, Angelica will not be subject to a due diligence penalty for Darren's misconduct. OPR must assess penalties against Darren.
options.D: Angelica will not be subject to a due diligence penalty for Darren's misconduct as long as she notifies all the clients about the errors on their returns.

questions.question_text: Hopedale Investments, Inc. is a calendar-year C corporation with 30 shareholders. After deducting business expenses, Hopedale Investments has $690,000 of income before taxes in 2024. The corporation also earns $120,000 of tax-exempt interest from municipal bonds. On December 31, Hopedale Investments distributes $240,000 in dividends to its shareholders. How are these transactions reported by the corporation and its shareholders?

options.A: Corporation: $120,000 of bond interest is excluded from taxable income; it receives no tax deduction for the distribution; Shareholders: The distribution is nontaxable.
options.B: Corporation: $120,000 of bond interest is excluded from taxable income to the corporation; no tax deduction for the distribution; Shareholders: Must recognize all the dividends as taxable income.
options.C: Corporation: $120,000 of bond interest is included in taxable income; distribution is taxable; Shareholders: Must recognize dividends as taxable income.
options.D: Corporation: $120,000 of bond interest is excluded from taxable income; distribution is taxable; Shareholders: Must recognize dividends as taxable income.

options.B: Kimberly can only be held responsible if she holds majority ownership in the company (greater than 50%).

options.C: He can rely on good faith without verification of information that Diana provides, but he must make reasonable inquiries if the information appears to be incorrect, inconsistent, or incomplete.

questions.question_text: Axiom Consulting, LLC, sells a factory building with an adjusted basis of $300,000. The buyer agrees to pay Axiom Consulting $600,000, with a cash down payment of $200,000 and $40,000 (plus 5% interest) in each of the next ten years. What is Axiom Consulting's gross profit and his gross profit percentage on this installment sale?

options.B: The gross profit is $10,000, and the gross profit percentage is 50%.

options.D: Lionel cannot rely on the work product of another preparer. He must figure out the carryover himself by requesting his clients prior-year records.

How should this transaction be classified?

options.A: The first $26,000 is taxable to the shareholder as a dividend. The remaining $4,000 is treated as a return of capital.
options.B: The entire $30,000 distribution is taxable to the shareholder as a dividend.
options.C: The first $26,000 is taxable to the shareholder as a dividend. The remaining $4,000 is taxable as a capital gain.
options.D: The first $20,000 is taxable to the shareholder as a dividend. The remaining $10,000 is taxable as a capital gain.

questions.question_text: Peggy sold two acres of land to her brother, Zeke on January 1. She realized a gain of $50,000 on the sale. Zeke agreed to pay her in five annual installments, and Peggy treats the sale as an installment sale. On November 1, eleven months after he purchased the land, Zeke sold the land to another person. Zeke plans to keep making installment payments based on their original agreement. How does this sale affect Peggy?

options.A: The new sale invalidates the earlier sale and Peggy will not have to report any gain.
options.B: There is no effect to Peggy from Zeke's sale of the land to another party.
options.C: The installment sale method is disallowed to Peggy, and Peggy must report the entire gain of $50,000 on the sale, even though she has not received all the installment payments.
options.D: Both Zeke and Peggy will face IRS penalties for selling the land before the required two-year holding period for installment sales between related persons.

questions.question_text: Kristen and Lindsey are roommates who live in a four-bedroom apartment. They use two bedrooms as personal bedrooms, and the other two rooms they use as offices. They are both self-employed graphic artists. Kristen uses 300 square feet of their apartment for her qualified business. Lindsey uses 200 square feet of their home for her separate qualified business. Both qualified businesses share 100 square feet for the storage of their own respective business materials. How should Kristen and Lindsey treat the shared space with regards to the home office deduction?

options.A: Kristen and Lindsey can deduct their home office expenses. For the shared storage space, they can both claim 50 of the 100 square feet or divide the 100 square feet between them in any reasonable manner.
options.B: Neither is eligible for a home office deduction.
options.C: They can both claim expenses for the shared space equally as if the space were not shared.
options.D: Kristen and Lindsey cannot claim the shared space as a deductible expense.

questions.question_text: Moises owns a van that he uses exclusively in his airport shuttle business. The van is totaled in an accident. It had been partially depreciated, and its adjusted basis was $28,000 at the time of the accident. Moises’s insurance company sends a check for $45,000 to replace the van. A week later, Moises uses the money to replace the van, paying an additional $4,000 out-of-pocket to purchase a new shuttle van. What is Moises’s basis in the new van and what is the taxable amount of this transaction?

options.A: $32,000 basis; $0 taxable gain.
options.B: $45,000 basis; $0 taxable gain.
options.C: $45,000 basis: $21,000 taxable gain.
options.D: $49,000 basis; $4,000 taxable gain.

options.A: $0, none of his benefits would be taxable.
options.B: $9,775, a maximum of 85% of his benefits would be taxable.
options.C: Insufficient information to determine the answer.
options.D: $11,500, all of his benefits would be taxable.

options.C: Toby needs to speak with his employers so that they refund excess Social Security taxes to him.
options.D: Both, Toby and his employers are entitled to a refund of excess Social Security taxes.
